Graphical abstract A series of K-Co|α-Al2O3 catalysts doped with potassium in the range of 0–4 wt% were synthesized and studied in the ethanol steam reforming process. The enhancement of activity and selectivity of the Co|α-Al2O3 catalyst upon the K doping was explained by potassium impact on the reducibility of the cobalt oxide precursor and acidity of the catalyst: K promotor inhibited the cobalt reduction and substantially increased the number of strong Lewis sites. The investigations of the surface state of potassium using a species resolved thermal alkali desorption method allowed for defining optimal potassium dispersion accurately, corresponding to the concentration of 0.3 wt%. Samples with higher potassium contents due to the overloading did not exhibit any improvement of the catalyst efficiency. Presented studies revealed the key importance of the precise optimization of the K loading and dispersion on the Co|α-Al2O3 catalyst for efficient hydrogen production via the ethanol steam reforming process. Keywords Hydrogen production Ethanol steam reforming Cobalt catalyst Potassium application FT-IR measurement Thermal alkali desorption 1 Introduction The promotional effect of alkali admixtures, mainly potassium, has been widely studied in numerous catalytic reactions, e.g., ethylbenzene dehydrogenation [1–3], water gas shift [4], ammonia synthesis [5–7] as well as decomposition [8–10], soot combustion [11–13] or N2O decomposition [14–16]. It has been found that the alkali addition may influence the performance of the catalyst by improving its activity, selectivity, or stability [17]. Recently, the alkali promotion is also a subject of extensive research in the context of effective hydrogen production via the ethanol steam reforming (ESR) [18–26], being an extremely important process because of the dynamic increase in interest in renewable energy sources [27–32]. Hydrogen indicated as a next-generation fuel for transportation and stationary applications can be produced from bioethanol derived from biomass. The advantage of such a source of hydrogen is its wide availability, as it can be produced from several biomass sources, which is relatively low cost [28,32–34]. An equally important advantage of bioethanol is its low toxicity and high security of storage and delivery. Moreover, due to the high hydrogen content, bioethanol molecule ensures high efficiency of the reforming processes (e.g. steam reforming). Promising results in the ESR process have been obtained for a large number of heterogeneous catalysts based on the various metallic active phases (Rh, Ru, Pt, Pd, Ir, Ni, Co, Cu, and Fe) dispersed on oxide carriers (Al2O3, CeO2, MgO, ZnO, ZrO2, and SiO2) [22,25,35–48]. Nevertheless, because the noble metal catalysts are costly, the most investigated for the hydrogen production via the ESR route are the much cheaper and widely available Ni- and Co-based materials. Unfortunately, although they exhibit high activity, they deactivate quite quickly due to undesirable processes, mainly coke deposition, active phase modification (sintering of the nanograins, changes in the oxidation state) poisoning by the bioethanol impurities [22,49–51]. Therefore, new solutions that could provide an adequate practical hydrogen production capacity are still being sought. One of the promising possibilities for cobalt or nickel-based catalysts for the ESR process is alkali promoters' application [18–24,27,41,42,49,51]. The authors are linking the substantial promotional effect of alkali on the operation of the catalysts, mainly with the abatement of carbon deposition [18,19,24,49]. There are also some reports, which indicate a direct relationship between the positive effect of alkali doping and the modification of the catalyst acidity [24,52]. For instance, N. Yu et al. [24] reported that K-doping modified the surface acid-basic properties of the Ni-Cu-Mg-Ce-O/Al2O3 catalyst, giving priority to the gasification and water-gas shift reactions [24]. The cobalt oxidation state is also essential and can be modified by alkali promoters as well [20,53,54]. In fact, the alkali addition can impact several catalyst features simultaneously [20,55]. Thus, the exact role of alkali depends strongly on the nature of the catalytic system, e.g. the type and dispersion of the active phase, the phase composition and morphology of the support, and has to be elucidated individually for each system. The crucial point in the alkali promotion of the catalyst is the promoter loading [23,56]. Although, there are some studies on the potassium doped alpha alumina catalyst, see for example a recent paper by Davies et al. [13], however, there is a lack of comprehensive studies in the context of the K-promoted alpha alumina supported catalysts for the ESR process. The alfa polymorph of Al2O3 is characterized by low surface acidity (in contrast to the strongly acidic γ-Al2O3 oxide) desired for the ESR process, in order to prevent C2H4 formation by ethanol dehydration path. Since α-Al2O3 is a low cost, widely available, and mechanically resistant material, it seems perfect for industrial application. Moreover, as reported by F. Schüth, the use of mechanochemical dehydration of boehmite (γ-AlOOH) allows obtaining the alpha phase of Al2O3 with a relatively high surface area [57], which seems to be an interesting point for further research. In our previous work, the potassium doping of the alumina supported cobalt catalyst at the level of 0.2 wt% was reported to influence the cobalt reducibility and surface concentration and strength of Lewis acid sites by stabilizing the excellent dispersion of the cobalt phase and finally preventing their removal from the catalyst surface by the carbon fibers formed during the ESR process [54]. We have also shown that an exclusive Species Resolved Thermal Alkali Desorption (SR-TAD) method provides unique data for understanding the alkali surface state (location, dynamics) and their impact on the catalyst properties and catalytic performance. In this work, we aimed at systematic and rational optimization of the potassium loading for the Co|Al2O3 catalyst for effective hydrogen production via ethanol steam reforming. We used the unique species resolved – thermal alkali desorption studies as a significant complement to the performed characterization of the morphology (HRTEM/EDX), acidity (pyridine sorption FT-IR studies), reducibility (H2-TPR) of the catalysts, as well as their catalytic performance. The investigations of the surface state of potassium using a SR-TAD method allowed for the precise optimization of the potassium promoter loading. To our best knowledge, such a comprehensive analysis of the relationship between the potassium surface state, catalysts' functional properties, and the activity is reported for the first time. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation The series of potassium doped Co|α-Al2O3 materials was synthesized. The α-Al2O3 support (surface area of 3 m2∙ g−1) was delivered by the New Chemical Synthesis Institute in Puławy (Poland). The Co3O4 phase was supported on alumina by incipient wetness impregnation using a water − glycerol (30 vol% of glycerol) solution of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (Sigma-Aldrich, 98%) with an appropriate concentration to obtain the spinel content of 10 wt%. The samples were next dried at 100 °C for 12 h and calcined in air at 500 °C for 4 h [58]. The potassium promoter in the amount of 0–4 wt% was introduced by the incipient wetness impregnation method, using KNO3 aqueous solutions with appropriate concentrations. After impregnation, the catalysts were dried at 100 °C for 24 h, and calcinated in the air at 500 °C for 4 h. As-prepared materials were reduced before the activity tests. 2.2 Characterization methods The elemental composition of obtained samples was verified employing the XRF spectrometer (ARL QUANT’X). The Rh anode was applied to generate the X-rays of 4−50 kV (1 kV step). The 3.5 mm Si(Li) drifted crystal with the Peltier cooling (∼ 185 K) was applied as a detector. The UniQuant software was used for the evaluation of the registered data. The phase composition of the samples was investigated using the X-ray diffractometer (Bruker D8-advance). The diffraction patterns were taken (2 theta between 20° and 100°, step of 0.02°, time of 3 s per step) using the CuK α radiation of λ=1.54 Å. Additionally, the micro-Raman spectroscopy was applied to confirm the spinel structure of the cobalt phase present in the as-prepared samples. The Raman spectra (in the range of 100–1000 cm−1, resolution of 1 cm–1) were recorded at room temperature using a Renishaw InVia spectrometer equipped with 785 nm laser and a confocal Leica DMLM microscope with a CCD detector. A satisfactory signal-to-noise ratio was ensured by collecting ten scans for each measurement. The morphological characterization of the samples was done using the scanning transmission electron microscope (Titan G2 60−300 kV, FEI Company) with an accelerating voltage of the electron beam equal to 300 kV (the experimental details described elsewhere [22,59]). Information on the distribution of the elements was obtained by energy dispersion X-ray spectroscopy (EDX). The mapping was carried out in the STEM mode. Phase separation in the cobalt-based catalysts was performed with the FFT by using masking available in the Gatan DigitalMicrograph software package. The samples reducibility was studied using the AutoChem II 2920 (Micromeritics) instrument. The TPR measurements were preceded by the thermal treatment with the flow of 5% O2/Ar at 550 °C, ensuring the sample purification (removal of impurities such as H2O, CO2, etc). The right H2-TPR measurement was carried out by passing the mixture of 5% H2/Ar at the rate of 30 cm3∙ min−1 over 0.15 g (0.3−0.6 mm) of the sample for temperature range from room temperature till 900 °C (10 °C min−1). The properties of Lewis acid centers were testified by pyridine as a probe in the FT-IR studies. The FT-IR quantitative measurements provided information about both the number of Lewis centers and their strength. The sample (20 mg) was formed into a pellet by mixing with silica (20 mg, Sigma Aldrich), placed in a quartz cell, and evacuated for 1 h at 550 °C in the pure hydrogen stream. Then, it was contacted with pyridine vapors at 100 °C. The gaseous and physisorbed molecules were removed from the catalyst surface by the 10 min cautious evacuation at the same temperature. The Lewis acid sites’ density was calculated from the intensity of the 1450 cm−1 band assigned to pyridine interacting with Lewis sites (PyL) and the value of its absorption coefficient (0.1 μmol/cm2). Finally, the number of Lewis acid sites was corrected with the number of acid sites found for silica. The potassium promoter's thermal desorption from the K-doped samples was investigated using a unique Species Resolved Thermal Alkali Desorption (SR-TAD) method. The potassium atoms desorption flux was traced with a surface ionization detector according to the procedure described in detail in ref. [54]. The registered data were evaluated using the Arrhenius equation to determine the activation energy of K desorption [5,60]. 2.3 Catalytic tests Catalytic activity testing was conducted in a Microactivity Reference unit (PID Eng & Tech.) in a continuous flow reactor with a fixed bed of catalyst (reactor diameter was 10 mm). The activity tests were performed under atmospheric pressure at a temperature of 500 °C. Prior to the catalytic reaction, 100 mg of sample, diluted with quartz and placed in a quartz tube, was reduced in situ with H2 flow (100 cm3 min−1, 550 °C, 1 h). The mixture of ethanol and water with their molar ratio of 1:4 were fed to the reactor at an actual flow rate of 38.5 cm3 min−1 diluted with argon with a flow rate of 61.5 mL/min−1. Activity tests described above, for which GHSV was equal to 60000 cm3∙ g−1∙ h−1, were complemented by the measurements of initial ethanol conversion using higher GHSV = 300000 cm3∙ g−1∙ h−1 (the increase in GHSV was achieved by reducing the sample mass from 100 mg to 20 mg). The composition of the reaction mixture was analyzed on-line by gas chromatography (Bruker 430-GC and Bruker 450-GC) containing TCD detectors and three columns: Molsieve 5 Å, Porapak Q, and CP-Molsieve 5 Å. More details were reported in the previous studies [61,62]. The conversion of ethanol ( X EtOH ) and the selectivity to carbon-containing products ( X CP ) were calculated based on Eq.s 1 and 2: (1) X E t O H = C E t O H i n − C E t O H o u t C E t O H i n × 100 % (2) X C P = n i C i o u t ∑ n i C i o u t × 100 % where: C E t O H i n - the EtOH concentration in the reaction mixture (mol%); C E t O H o u t - the EtOH concentration in the post-reaction mixture (mol%); C i out - the concentration of carbon-containing product in the post-reaction mixture (mol%); n i –the number of carbon atoms in a carbon-containing molecule of the reaction product. The selectivity of hydrogen formation was calculated from: (3) H 2 selectivity = C H 2 out C H 2 out + 2 × C C H 4 out + 2 × C C 2 H 4 o u t + 2 × C C H 3 CHO out + 3 × C ( C H 3 ) 2 CO out × 100 % where: C out - the concentration of the hydrogen-containing products in the post-reaction mixture (mol%). The results presented below (ethanol conversion, selectivity to individual products) were calculated as the average of the three measurements recorded close in time, from which the error bars were determined. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization The results of XRF studies for the series of synthesized K-Co|α-Al2O3 catalyst precursors, presented in Table 1 (expressed as oxides), showed that the assumed content of the cobalt phase and potassium admixture were obtained with satisfactory accuracy. The XRD and Raman Spectroscopy (Fig. S1) results indicated the presence of the Co3O4 as the only cobalt speciation form. Besides, the XRD results confirmed the presence of the alpha-alumina as a support and its phase purity [63]. The microscopic observations (Fig. 1 ) disclosed the uniform high dispersion of the cobalt spinel phase on the alumina support for all the examined samples, i.e. 0 wt%K, 0.3 wt%K, and 1.5 wt%K. The HRTEM images in Fig. 1(A1–C4) together with the complementary FFT (Fig. 1 A3,B3,C3) and phase identification (Fig. 1 A4,B4,C4) show the Co3O4 nanograins of the average size in the range of 10–50 nm dispersed on the micron-size grains of the alpha-alumina support. Based on the phase identification, no crystalline phases with the potassium promoter were detected. It suggests that the potassium promoter does not form any crystalline structures with cobalt or alumina support of the fresh catalysts. It is consistent with the work of Ogo et al. [20], which showed that the addition of the potassium promoter to the cobalt catalyst led to the surrounding of the cobalt active phase with an amorphous potassium compound. The impact of potassium doping on the reducibility of catalyst precursor is presented in Fig. 2 . For the 0 wt%K, 0.1 wt%K, and 0.3 wt%K samples (Fig. 2a) the TPR profiles showed several maxima at ca. 300, 360, 610, and 680 °C, identifying the Co3+→ Co2+ and Co2+→ Co0 reduction processes [58]. A small addition of potassium (up to 0.3% by weight) results in the first peak intensity decrease and its shift towards lower temperatures. In turn, the second maximum shifted towards higher temperatures, while its intensity increased. Such behavior of the low-content K samples indicates a significant impact of the K doping on the cobalt active phase's reducibility. High-temperature reduction peak (600–750 °C) observed for the 0.1 wt%K and 0.3 wt%K samples is not typical of the bulk Co3O4 spinel [58]. It is assigned to a formation of either surface KxCoO2 phase (see reference TPR profile for bulk KxCoO2, Fig. S2) or, less likely, the surface mixed Co-Al oxide phases [63]. Then, for the higher potassium content, starting with a 0.5 wt%, the TPR profiles changed significantly (Fig. 2b). The appearance of the intense sharp peaks in the range of 300−500 °C most likely results from the presence of a significant amount of nitrate residues accumulated on the catalyst surface [64,65]. Indeed, the existence of such H2-TPR peaks was explained by the relatively high fraction of alkali nitrate that remained stable on the catalyst surface even after the calcination treatment at 600 °C [62]. Also, we observed peaks in this range on the H2-TPR curve of the alpha alumina support doped with potassium nitrate (Fig. S2). At the same time, in the FT-IR spectrum of the potassium-doped sample appeared peaks in the range of 1500−1300 cm−1 which is diagnostic for both nitrates (originating from Co and K precursors) and carbonates species [66] (formed by the interaction of CO2 with alumina and potassium oxide) on the catalyst surface (Fig. S3). The 1630 cm−1 band can be assigned to either water or bidentate nitrates bonded to the alumina surface. The significant intensity of the carbonates and nitrates bands for the K-doped sample, in contrast to the 0 wt%K sample (Fig. S3), evidences that the presence of potassium facilitates the storage of nitrates and carbonates on the catalysts’ surfaces. In the light of the above, the presence of potassium in the form of nitrate or carbonate seems to be justified. Both the cobalt phase and potassium presence influence the acidic surface features. Then, the impact of potassium on acidic properties of the Co|α-Al2O3 catalyst surface was examined in the pyridine sorption FT-IR studies (Fig. 3 ). For all the studied samples, the spectra revealed only the bands of PyL adducts, signifying the presence of the sites able to bond Py coordinatively. An additional band at 1437 cm−1 (very intense for the sample 4 wt%K) originates from the physisorbed Py molecules. Two bands observed in the spectrum for Py adsorbed on Al2O3 indicates the presence of two types of Lewis sites differing in the acid strength (Fig. 3b). The higher frequency band (ca. 1452 cm−1) is attributed to pyridine bonded to the sites of high electron acceptor properties, i.e. high acid strength, greatly populated on Al2O3. The addition of potassium (sample K-α-Al2O3) did not significantly affect the picture of the acidic properties of the alumina surface. Significant changes were noticed, however, for the Co|α-Al2O3 samples (Fig. 3a) denoted as 0 wt%K. A substantial increase in the intensity of PyL bands indicates the appearance of a significant number of electron acceptor sites in the presence of the Co phase on the Al2O3 support. The presence of the 1452 cm−1 band indicates either the formation of a small number of highly acidic sites or the presence of alumina-origin Lewis sites unperturbed by Co-deposition. The increase in the intensity of the 1445 cm−1 band, assigned to medium acid strength sites, documents the formation of new sites of weaker electron donor properties associated with the cobalt species. The modification of the acid properties of the Co|α-Al2O3 catalyst by the potassium addition is undeniably more relevant than that found for pure Al2O3. For all the K-Co|α-Al2O3 catalysts, an increase in the number of strong acid sites (1452 cm−1) was observed at the expense of the sites of lower strength (1445 cm−1). This points to an essential role of potassium in the modification of the Co|α-Al2O3 catalyst surface acidity, which is, what should be underlined, associated with the spinel phase only. Nevertheless, after an initial increase in the number of strong Lewis centers (1452 cm−1) with potassium loading, the observed relationship flattened, reaching a plateau for samples with a potassium loading above 0.5 wt% (Fig. 3c). This strongly suggests that exceeding the potassium loading causes its segregation on the surface of the catalyst and, consequently, suppress its actions on the catalyst properties, including acidity. The relationship mentioned above influences the catalytic activity in the ESR process as will be documented in the next chapter. 3.2 Catalysts activity and selectivity in the ESR process At the very beginning of the ESR process (Fig. 4 a; T =500 °C, EtOH/H2O = 1:4; GHSV = 60000 cm3∙ g−1∙ h−1), the ethanol conversion over the Co|α-Al2O3 catalyst was only 60%, but the addition of potassium allowed to achieve a complete ethanol conversion over all the catalysts containing the promoter, i.e. in the range of its content from 0.1–4 wt%. After that, all the catalysts were deactivated over time-on-stream, with the ethanol conversion dropping faster for potassium doped catalysts. The rate of the deactivation of the K-doped catalysts clearly depends on the promoter content; it decreases with its increase in the range of 0.1–1.5 wt%. Whereas, the catalysts containing 4 wt% of potassium exhibits the deactivation rate comparable to that observed for the catalyst with 0.3 wt% of the promoter. Although the rate of catalyst deactivation depends on the potassium loading, after 24 h of the ESR process, all the K-doped catalysts show the same conversion of approx. 60%, which means that the potassium loading does not affect the long-term stability of the Co|α-Al2O3 catalyst in the ESR process. The initial ethanol conversion of the studied catalysts was additionally tested for different reaction conditions (Fig. S5). An increase in the GHSV up to 300000 cm3⋅ g−1⋅ h−1 brought down the ethanol conversion, demonstrating the difference in the initial conversion of the catalysts. As presented in Fig. S5, the conversion in the 20th minute of the experiment increased significantly with the K loading. Then, the catalysts deactivated over time (the deactivation rate increases significantly with K loading), and apparently approaching a constant value, in line with the results for the lower GHSV (Fig. 4). It should be emphasized that regardless of the potassium content, it improves the activity of the catalyst in cleaving the CC bond. Within 24 h of the ESR reaction, the ethanol conversion over all the potassium-containing catalysts is higher (60%) compared with that obtained for the undoped catalyst (ca. 50%). Considering the determined values of ethanol conversion and selectivity to individual products (Fig. S4), the potassium loading of 0.3 wt% is optimal for improving the performance of the Co|α-Al2O3 catalyst under the ESR conditions. As shown in Fig. 4b, both at the early course and after 24 h of the ESR reaction, the 0.3 wt%K sample exhibited a higher selectivity to the two most desirable products of the ESR reaction, hydrogen, and carbon dioxide, compared to the undoped catalyst. Furthermore, the 0.3 wt%K catalyst showed high selectivity towards C1 products, carbon monoxide, and methane, whereas a significant amount of a C2 product, i.e. acetaldehyde, was formed over the Co|α-Al2O3 catalyst. It suggests that the addition of potassium improves the ability of the Co|α-Al2O3 catalyst to the CC bond cleavage. In line with previous reports [54], the ethanol dehydrogenation to acetaldehyde is considered as the first key step of ethanol transformation in the presence of studied catalysts. Still, the 0.3 wt%K catalyst facilitates the decomposition of acetaldehyde to CH4 and CO to a greater extent than the promoter-free catalyst. Moreover, at the beginning of the ESR process, among the by-products for the Co|α-Al2O3 catalyst, the trace amounts of the product C3, i.e. acetone, was detected as a result of the aldol condensation of acetaldehyde. However, after the 24 h of process, neither the Co|α-Al2O3 nor the 0.3 wt%K catalyst lead to the acetone production (Figs. 4c, S4). In contrast, other products observed at the beginning of the ESR reaction, i.e. hydrogen, carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide, methane, and acetaldehyde, were still detected in the outlet for both catalysts. Although the product distribution changed with the increase in time-on-stream, it remained more favorable for the 0.3 wt%K catalyst. The outcomes of the activity tests correspond well with the TPR and FT-IR results presented above. The assumption of K segregation in cases of catalysts with K loading higher than 0.3 wt% seems to be credible in the light of the described dependence of catalyst performance on the K content. In order to verify the set hypothesis, the thermal potassium desorption studies were performed. 3.3 Catalysts characterization after the ESR process The TEM images of the 0 wt%K, 0.3 wt%K, and 1.5 wt%K catalysts after 24 h of the ESR process are presented in Fig. 5 . Almost complete removal of the cobalt nanocrystals from the surface of the Al2O3 support can be seen for the 0 wt%K catalyst (Fig. 5 A1), whereas the initial high dispersion of the cobalt phase (see Fig. 1) is preserved for both catalysts doped with K (Fig. 5A2,A3). The more precise TEM images presented in Fig. 6 show the detached cobalt phase nanocrystals inside the carbon deposit for the 0 wt%K sample (Fig. 6A1) and the cobalt phase being still in contact with alumina support for 0.3 wt%K and 1.5 wt%K samples (Fig. 6B1, C1a). In turn, the image of the cobalt nanograin attached to the tip of the carbon fiber illustrates the process of the carbon fiber growing during the ESR reaction (Fig.6C1b). Undoubtedly, for the undoped catalyst, the formation of carbon deposit separates the cobalt phase from the support to a great extent, and for the K-doped catalysts much less. As can be seen in detail in Fig. 7 , the units of carbon deposit contain the cobalt nanograins enclosed inside the fibers (Fig. 7C1) as well as located at their tip (Fig. 7C2). These results demonstrate that the presence of potassium significantly enhances the interaction between the alumina and cobalt active phases, being consistent with our previous work [54]. The strong cobalt-support interaction, assured by the potassium presence in the required amount, results in stabilization of the active phase preventing its removal from the Al2O3 surface. The FFT method (Figs. 6,7) revealed the presence of both metallic and oxide forms of the cobalt phase in the spent catalysts. The Co phase was identified from the interplanar distances of 1.92 Å and 2.05 Å corresponding to the (101) and (111) planes, respectively. The presence of CoO was acknowledged based on the interplanar distance of 2.12 Å, corresponding to the (200) plane. 3.4 Potassium promoter state at the catalyst surface The studies with the Species Resolved Thermal Alkali Desorption method (SR-TAD) showed that the potassium promotor surface dynamics strongly depends on its content (Fig. 8 ). First of all, the onset of the K atoms desorption flux observed at 500 °C for the 0.3 wt%K sample shifted to lower temperatures, while the potassium loading increased. The much more intense K desorption peak-shape signals registered for the 0.5 wt%K and 1.5 wt%K samples (two and three orders of magnitude larger, respectively), which started already at 400 °C, correspond to loosely bonded potassium agglomerated at the surface. The local maxima in the desorption signal for 1.5 wt%K correspond to different states of segregated potassium. The lack of such maxima for 0.3 wt%K sample indicates very good potassium dispersion without any segregation. Finally, it is stated that 0.3 wt% corresponds to optimal promoter content. The low potassium stability on the surface of 0.5 wt%K, and 1.5 wt%K catalysts, as well as 4 wt%K catalyst (not measured with SR-TAD method because of certainty that the K desorption flux will be even larger than for 1.5 wt%K), results in their rapid deactivation under the ESR process conditions (500 °C, 24 h) (see Fig. 4). After this time their preliminary high ethanol conversion reached the level for the 0.3 wt%K sample, for which K was stable up to 500 °C. The potassium promoter dynamics observed for the 0.3 wt%K sample ensure that it does not escape from the catalyst surface during the ESR process at this temperature. Besides, the result of the second run of the thermal desorption measurement for the 0.5 wt%K sample (Fig. S6) is comparable to the one for the 0.3 wt%K sample, indicating its complete surface cleaning from segregated potassium upon the first desorption run starting at low temperature (about 400 °C). Based on the potassium desorption signals, using the Arrhenius dependence, the activation energies of potassium desorption (E a) from the catalyst surface were determined for 0.3 wt%K and 0.5 wt%K (for the second run) samples (see Fig. S6). Three activation energies, 2.8 eV, 1.9 eV, and 1.4 eV, typical for oxide materials [54,67], were observed. According to the previously performed SR-TAD measurements for the reference systems such as K-Co3O4 (∼2.5 eV), K-CoO (∼2.0 eV), and K-α-Al2O3 (∼1.4 eV) [54], values measured herein were assigned. Two energies determined for the 0.3 wt%K sample correspond to the potassium desorption from Co3O4 oxide and alumina support. In contrast, the energy determined for the 0.5 wt%K sample corresponds to the potassium desorption from CoO oxide, arising from a partial surface reduction (in vacuum conditions during the first run of the thermal treatment). The potassium promoter distribution found for the 0.3 wt%K sample, also observed from EDX mapping (Fig. S7), indicates its quite uniform surface dispersion between the cobalt phase and the alumina support. Also, the presence of energies representative for both Co3O4 oxide and alumina support indicates the migration of the potassium promoter from cobalt nanograins towards the alumina support upon the temperature treatment. Such behavior of potassium promoter was also reported in [13], where the potassium dispersion and mobility were investigated by XANES. 4 Conclusions The series of K-Co|α-Al2O3 catalysts doped with potassium in the range of 0–4 wt% was thoroughly characterized (XRD, RS, H2-TPR, FT-IR, HRTEM/EDX, and SR-TAD) and evaluated for activity in the ethanol steam reforming (ESR) process. The optimal potassium content was documented as the factor ruling the efficiency of the ESR catalyst. Following the changes in the Co|α-Al2O3 catalyst acidity (FT-IR studies of pyridine sorption), reducibility (H2-TPR), the potassium thermal stability (SR-TAD), and the enhancement of the Co|α-Al2O3 catalyst performance the optimal potassium of 0.3 wt% was established. The addition of low potassium content (0.3% by weight) significantly increased the number of strong Lewis acid sites, inhibited the cobalt reduction, and improved the catalyst efficiency. In contrast, no further enhancement of catalyst acidity or activity was observed for higher potassium loading, signifying K segregation in the catalysts with loading greater than 0.3 wt%. In the case of these samples, the potassium overloading was directly pointed out by the potassium surface state studies using a unique species resolved – thermal alkali desorption method (SR-TAD). The results confirmed that the precious control of potassium loading and surface state is demanding for assuring the high catalytic performance of Co|Al2O3 catalyst in the ESR process. coredata.dc:description: A series of K-Co|α-Al2O3 catalysts doped with potassium in the range of 0–4 wt% were synthesized and studied in the ethanol steam reforming process. The enhancement of activity and selectivity of the Co|α-Al2O3 catalyst upon the K doping was explained by potassium impact on the reducibility of the cobalt oxide precursor and acidity of the catalyst: K promotor inhibited the cobalt reduction and substantially increased the number of strong Lewis sites. The investigations of the surface state of potassium using a species resolved thermal alkali desorption method allowed for defining optimal potassium dispersion accurately, corresponding to the concentration of 0.3 wt%. Samples with higher potassium contents due to the overloading did not exhibit any improvement of the catalyst efficiency. Presented studies revealed the key importance of the precise optimization of the K loading and dispersion on the Co|α-Al2O3 catalyst for efficient hydrogen production via the ethanol steam reforming process.
coredata.dc:title: Optimization of the potassium promotion of the Co|α-Al2O3 catalyst for the effective hydrogen production via ethanol steam reforming
